journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A comprehensive dynamic model of electric overhead cranes and the lifting operations

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Structure Analysis for Industrial Equipment, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, People's Republic of China
2School of Engineering, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK

author-notes.corresp: *School of Engineering, University of Liverpool, Liverpool L69 3GH, UK. email: h.ouyang@liverpool.ac.uk

abstract.p: The design of electric cranes requires knowledge of not only the dynamic loads acting on the mechanisms and the structure, and the movement of the crane and payload during their various operations, but also the electromagnetic characteristics of the control system. This article puts forward a new comprehensive dynamic model for the whole system of electric cranes, which includes the mechanisms, the steel structure, the induction motors, and their drive systems. A general electric overhead travelling crane controlled by two types of control schemes (of changing the rotor resistance and the closed-loop rotor-flux-oriented vector control) during the operation of its lifting mechanism is studied. Hamilton's principle with a modified Lagrangian, and the theory of induction motors and drive systems are combined to build a dynamic model of electric cranes during lifting operations. This model aims at simulating the dynamic behaviour of the mechanical and structural systems for the transient and steady-state behaviour of the induction motors and their control during the operations of a real crane. It can be seen that the dynamic system of the whole crane is highly non-linear and non-stationary even for only the lifting operation.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Every electric crane at work is an electromechanical coupled dynamic system which contains energy storage elements, and not only mechanisms and structures but also driving motors. In addition, due to the intermittent and repeated nature of its operations, transient vibration takes place frequently. The transient dynamic behaviour is a vitally important problem for crane designers, manufacturers, and users, and involves all aspects of cranes, such as strength, rigidity, stability, lifespan, productivity, even comfort, and health of operators. Therefore, the time history ofthe mechanical, structural, and electromagnetic loads in cranes during operations must be carefully considered in the design of cranes. Along with the trend towards high speed and heavy load, more attention should be paid to the dynamic behaviour of the components of cranes.

It is very important to investigate the interaction among crane components and determine more accurately the time history and characteristics of loads in the mechanisms, the structure, and the electrical system during all kinds of crane operations from a global standpoint in the design stage for predicting and evaluating lifespan of cranes and their components, enhancing control, improving cranes' working performance, and developing new lightweight products. Riikonen [1] (the Convener of CEN/TC 147/WGP4 – Bridge and Gantry Cranes and a former Chairman of ISO/TC 96/SC9 – Bridge and Gantry Cranes) reported the conclusion drawn by Rudolf Neugebauer (the Drafter of EN13001), who studied numerous failure cases of cranes, that it is necessary to determine the real stress cycles more accurately than in the past. The objective of this article is to present a proposal for estimating more detailed and accurate dynamic response information of electric cranes during operations by considering the whole crane system and predicting the load spectrum ofcomponents of a real crane (which has a rapid working cycle) at the beginning of its design phase.

There are many more published works on the sway and position control of crane operations such as Moustafa et al. [2] and Neupert et al. [3] than those on dynamic responses of components of cranes. Some works belonging to the latter category are briefly reviewed here. Oguamanam et al. [4] studied the transverse vibration of the girder and the dynamics of the payload during the traversing operation of an overhead crane. Their crane consisted of an Euler–Bernoulli beam, a point mass trolley moving along the girder with a prescribed uniform velocity, and a point mass payload suspended from the trolley by a massless rigid rod. Based on the technique presented in Wu et al. [5], Wu [6, 7] investigated the vibration of a three-dimensional gantry of a tyred gantry crane and the frame structure due to a traversing trolley with a payload, respectively. The trolley and payload were modelled as a swaying lumped mass with a prescribed speed as a trapezium-shaped function of time. However, the Coriolis and centrifugal forces due to the moving trolley with the payload were not included in Wu [6]. Zrnić et al. [8] presented an equivalent model obtained by the finite element method of a quayside container crane to calculate the dynamic deflection and bending moment of the boom during quay-to-ship load transfer. In this model, the trolley is considered as a moving mass that traverses the boom with distributed parameters on elastic supports with lumped masses attached. The elastic supports modelled as springs are used to include the elastic effect of all other parts of the upper structure of the crane except the boom and the mass fixed on them from the forestays’ weight.

Jerman [9] and Jerman and Kramar [10] investigated the dynamics of the steel structure and slewing mechanism of an electric tower crane during slewing motion in a non-linear dynamic model. The rotation of the cage motor is specified as an input function of time in the model. Ju et al. [11] studied the dynamic response of the tower structure of a tower crane induced by the spherical and planar pendulum motion of the payload using a dynamic model for the mast, the jib, the rope, and the payload mass. Sun and Kleeberger [12] presented a method for calculating the dynamic response of the steel structure, wire rope, and the output torque from the hydraulic motor of a hydraulic mobile crane. The finite element model of the structure and the wire rope are coupled with the model of the hydraulic drive and control system.

Kiliçslan et al. [13] investigated the dynamic characteristics of a mobile crane while the boom was being hoisted, by a multibody dynamics approach to determine the safety load to prevent tipping. Only the boom was assumed to be flexible, and the motion of the piston used for hoisting the boom was specified by a velocity–time profile. Sağirli et al. [14] used the bond graph method to build a non-linear dynamic model of a truck crane for the main structure and the rotating mechanism, and the lifting mechanism driven by hydraulic cylinders. The model was used to analyse the dynamic response during the rotary motion and load-lifting motion. Using a dynamic model of rigid–flexible body for the motion of the slewing mechanism and the drum prescribed by functions of time, Maczynski and Wojciech [15] studied the dynamics of a mobile telescopic crane during the slewing movement and proposed an optimization strategy on payload positioning at the end of a slewing cycle. Towarek [16] focused his attention on the dynamic stability of the boom crane due to the interaction between the soil foundation (as Kelvin–Voigt bodies) and the crane (modelled as multibodies). Cha et al. [17] studied the motion of a floating crane carrying a heavy cargo and the rope load when the cargo is being suspended by the method of multibody dynamics.

The electromagnetic torque of drive motors in an electric crane is the most complicated internal excitation as a result of the dynamic interaction between their electrical, mechanical, and structural subsystems. In addition, the characteristics of the electromagnetic torque are different for different motor drive control systems. For these reasons, the solution of dynamic response of the crane system during operations should be determined naturally from the whole interaction process between mechanical and electrical systems (but not from the electro-magnetic torque of drive motors or the motion of the mechanisms prescribed in advance).

Without question, a suitable consideration of theelectromechanical system dynamics for cranes during operations will allow accurate prediction of the dynamic behaviour of cranes and enhance the safety of operations and the lifespan of these very useful machines. To the authors’ best knowledge, there has not been any published research work that integrates the structural, mechanical, and electric subsystems of whole electric cranes. The purpose of this article is to present a general mathematical modelling approach of system dynamics of electric cranes during operations which can be used to analyse dynamic responses of the electromagnetism, mechanism, and structure during the operations of electric cranes. Thereby, the strength, rigidity, and in particular the lifespan of cranes and their components with a rapid working cycle can be evaluated more accurately by combining the behaviour of motor control system and the transient state of the induction motor to the dynamic analysis during operations.

sec.title: 2 FUNDAMENTAL ASSUMPTIONS
sec.p:
Considering the features of electric overhead cranes [18, 19] and for the purpose of simplifying dynamic analysis, the following fundamental assumptions are made:
The clearance between mechanical driving elements, and the bending of driving shafts are neglected.
The stators and rotors in motors and motors’ enclosures, couplings, braking drums (or discs), the rope drum, gears and gear reducers’ cases, sheaves, the trolley frame, wheels, end carriages,the load-handling device, and the payload are considered rigid bodies.
The wire rope is a massless elastic body with a constant modulus of elasticity, and viscous damping and can withstand only axial tension. Two girders are Euler beams with the same small curvature, uniform damping and mass, and the elastic property.
The rated braking capacity of the mechanical brake stays constant.
The iron loss, electromagnetic radiation, and the motor parameter variation due to temperature are neglected. The gap between stator and rotor is uniform and the coupling magnetic field is linear in the three-phase AC symmetrical induction motor.
The power electronic switches in the motor drive system are ideal switches.

sec.title: 3.1.1 Physical model
sec.p:
The physical model of an electric overhead crane during the lifting operation is shown in Fig. 1. In the model, the rotating parts of the lifting mechanism (from its motor rotor to its drum) can be thought as a two-degree-of-freedom spring–mass subsystem rotating about the axis through the disc centres Od1 and Od2, although more degrees of freedom can be given to it. Fig. 1
Physical model of a general electric overhead crane during lifting operation

sec.title: 3.1.2 Energy in structure
sec.p:
A reference frame OXYZ is illustrated in Fig. 1, whose X-axis is in the direction of the travelling mechanism. Because there is a curvature on the top of the cross-section of crane rail and a gap between the flanges of crane wheels and two sides of the rails, the contact between the wheels and the rails cannot constrain the rotation of the sections of the girders at two ends [19]. Therefore, the girders are assumed to be simply supported beams and the elastic deformation of the girders due to vertical loads relative to the position under their dead weight [20] can be assumed as (1) where
and y is the Y-coordinate of any section of the girder in the OXYZ frame.

Let the potential energy of two girders at the position under their dead weight be zero. The elastic potential energyV1and kinetic energyT1 of two girders can be derived as (for example, from Yu [20]) (2) (3) where

sec.title: 3.1.3 Energy in lifting mechanism
sec.p: The energy of the lifting mechanism includes the kinetic energy T2 owing to the rotation of rigid bodies about the axis through the disc centres Od1andOd2 and the elastic potential energy V2 due to torsion of the elastic shaft and tension of the wire rope including the part wrapping around the drum. They are (4) (5) with

sec.title: 3.1.4 Energy of trolley and payload
sec.p:
Take the four-wheel trolley as an example. A local coordinate system O3η3χ3ξ3 is defined, whoseη3 axis coincides with the wheels axis O3O3 ' of the trolley, as shown in Fig. 1. Given that plane XOY is taken as the zero position of the gravitational potential energy, the potential energy, and kinetic energy of the trolley and the payload are (6) (7) with
Here, ZQ and ZT are the Z-coordinates of the centre of mass of the payload including the load-handling device and the trolley, respectively. Ci (i = T, d) are constants associated with the elastic deformation under the dead weight, the camber and the sizes of the girder. Here, χd is the χ3-coordinate of the axis through disc centres Od1 and Od2 and χT the χ3-coordinate of the centre of gravity of trolley in the frame O3η3χ3ξ3.

It should be pointed out that the lifting operations under investigation are limited to cases when the travelling mechanism, which is located near the ends of the girder and experiences very little lateral vibration, is stationary; hence, the contribution of the travelling mechanism to the energy of the dynamic system is ignored.

sec.title: 3.1.5 Virtual work of non-conservative forces
sec.p:
In the dynamic system, the non-conservative forces are the braking torque of the mechanical brake Mb1andMb2, the friction force between the drum and the wire rope wrapping around it, the resisting torque in the lifting mechanism Mf, and the damping forces relating to the elastic components. Here, the damping forces in the elastic components and at the contact interfaces are considered as viscous damping and Coulomb friction, respectively. Suppose the directions of θ·d,θ·r,Mb1,Mb2, and Mf shown in Fig. 1 are positive. The virtual work of the non-conservative forces can be written as (8) with
Here, δWi(i=1,2,…,5) are the virtual work of the braking torque of the brakes, damping force of the elastic shafts, damping force in the wire rope and the friction force between the wire rope and the drum, the resistance force in the lifting mechanism, and the damping force in two girders, respectively. Mbsi is the braking capacity of the ith brake referred to the axis of the drum.

sec.title: 3.2 Three-phase AC symmetrical induction motor drive system
3.2.1 Voltage and flux linkage equation of induction motor
sec.p:
In general, three-phase symmetrical AC induction motors are adopted in the electric overhead cranes. The voltage equation and the flux linkage equation of the motor given in the coordinate form of the space vector of its electromagnetic quantities [21, 22] in stationary reference frame α O β, whose α-axis coincides with the axis of a-phase stator winding and β-axis is perpendicular to the α-axis in the anticlockwise direction, can be expressed as follows [22, 23], respectively. (9) (10) with
Here, tmsi and tmei are the starting and ending time of the interval when the power is supplied to stator windings of the motor, respectively. λi(i=s,r) are the vectors, whose entries are the coordinates of the stator and the rotor flux linkage space vectors in stationary reference frame α O β, respectively; and vs is a vector whose entries are the coordinates of the stator voltage space vector in stationary reference frame α O β. and u(t) a unit step function.

When a three-phase wound rotor motor is controlled by changing the rotor resistance, rr in equation (9) will include the external resistance and experience some step changes during starting and braking.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Magnetic co-energy in induction motor
sec.p:
The coupling magnetic field in a three-phase AC induction motor is a conservative energy storage space in the case of no core loss. Furthermore, the magnetic co-energy Vc in the motor can be obtained from equation (11) [23]. (11) with
where ijs( j=a,b,c) is the j-phase stator current and ijr( j=a,b,c) the j-phase rotor current referred to the stator.

sec.title: 3.2.3 Stator voltage of induction motor
sec.p: In electric cranes, various motor control schemes have been adopted in practice. Nowadays, variable frequency control is increasingly popular, but motor control by changing the rotor resistance is still usedfrequently when precise speed control is not required, due to its low cost.

sec.title: (i) Speed control by changing the rotor resistance
sec.p: When the motor speed control is implemented by changing the rotor resistance, a three-phase AC wound motor is used and a three-phase mains power is supplied directly to the three-phase stator windings generally [24]. The stator voltage vector will be (12) Here, aps is 1 or −1, which indicates the phase sequence of the three-phase stator winding.

On the other hand, it is likely that the motor will also be fed a single-phase voltage when the lifting mechanism with a light load works at low speed in the lowering direction in some speed control system by changing the rotor resistance [24]. In this case, the stator voltage vector becomes (13)

sec.title: (ii) Vector control
sec.p: Under the vector control, a three-phase stator winding of a three-phase AC induction motor with the squirrel cage rotor is fed by a three-phase voltage source bridge inverter. The inverter has three parallel legs. Each leg consists of two electronic power switches in series and each electronic power switch is anti-parallel with a diode. The conducting states of the two electronic power switches in thesame leg are complementary [22, 25].

Figure 2 shows the main circuit of the motor drive which includes an uncontrolled rectifier and DC link with the braking unit, filtering capacitors, and braking resistances besides the inverter and the three-phase AC induction motor. Fig. 2
Main circuit of a three-phase AC induction motor fed by voltage source inverter

During the control process, the DC link may be in the following three states: wheniin>0, the steady DC voltage from the capacitor with capacitance, Cf, can be applied to the inverter; when iin<0 and voltage Ud across the capacitor is not more than a limit voltage, Umax, the capacitor will be charged; when Ud>Umax, the electronic power switch, VTb, is turned on. Assuming that the current direction shown in Fig. 2 is positive, the current or voltage relationships corresponding to the three circuit states above are given by equations (14) to (16), respectively. (14) (15) (16) with
where Rb is the braking resistance and Uz the average output voltage of the uncontrolled rectifier. The meanings of other symbols can be found in Fig. 2.

The three terminals of a three-phase Y-connected stator winding are connected to the middle points ofthree legs of the inverter, respectively [22, 25]. Thus, the relationship between the DC link current iin and the currents in the three-phase stator winding can be found in (17) with
Here Si=1(i=a,b,c) is used to denote the switch states of a leg of the inverter when the top switch is on and the bottom one off. Conversely, Si=0(i=a,b,c).

There are different vector control schemes for a three-phase AC symmetrical induction motor [26]. The rotor flux orientation scheme is adopted more in practice. Figure 3 shows a basic rotor-flux-oriented scheme [21, 22, 25, 27–29]. Under the control scheme, the components of the required stator voltage space vector in a dOq frame rotating at the speed of θ∧·f, whose d-axis is at an angle of θ∧f to α -axis and q-axis is perpendicular to the d-axis in the anticlockwise direction, are determined by equations (18)–(21) according to reference stator currents im * and iT *. (18) (19) (20) (21) with
Here Ls *, Lr *,M*,and τr * are the stator inductance, the rotor inductance, the magnetizing inductance, and the rotor time constant in the digital signal processor (DSP), respectively. Fig. 3
Basic vector control scheme by rotor flux linkage orientation
It follows from the above that the amplitude and the phase angle within [0, 2π] in the α O β frame of vs v*, |vs v*| and θsref, are (22) Here k is an integer in order to let θsref∈[0,2π].

Based on vs v*, four switch states of a inverter connecting with two zero-voltage space vectors and two voltage space vectors, which are adjacent to vs v* in the form of ui=2Udej (i-1)π/3/3(i=1,2,…,6) generating a three-phase symmetrical pulse stator voltage series, their sequence, and durations in a pulse width modulation (PWM) period Ts, are determined by space vector PWM technology [22, 25, 26, 29]. The duration and the stator voltage vector, respectively, are (23) (24) with
Here t0 is the total duration of two zero voltage space vectors during Ts. ti and ti+1 are the durations of ui and ui+1 during Ts, respectively. τdf is the time constant of the low-pass filter for measuring dc voltage of the DC link. equation (23) is just suitable for the cases in which over-modulation does not appear. Otherwise, the duration of the active voltage space vectors and amplitude of vs v* have to be modified.

The scheme to determine the reference stator currents in a DSP from different manufacturers varies moderately. Suppose that the scheme shown in Fig.4 is adopted. The following relationships are valid (25) with
Here Tepi *is the reference electromagnetic torque given by PI controller 3.Tmax is the maximum allowed value of the electromagnetic torque. ωr,rate and ωr * are the rated rotor angular speed and the reference rotor electrical angular speed, respectively, and λr,rate and λr* the rated and the reference amplitudes of the rotor flux linkage space vector, respectively. Fig. 4
A scheme to determine reference stator currents

sec.title: 3.3 Constraints in mechanism and steel structure
sec.p:
Because the total free length of the wire rope remains constant during the operation of the lifting mechanism, l, θd,and ε are not independent variables. If the angular displacement θd is taken to be zero when the entire working turns of the wire rope is released from the drum and the strain of the wire rope is zero,l, θd,and ε are related by equation (26) (26) with
Here, l00 is the free length of the falling rope when both θd and ɛ are equal to zero.

When the payload is lifted from its support, a lifting operation may start with gradually stretching the wire rope. During such a hoisting process, the payload keeps still, but the strain and tension of the rope are increasing until the payload is lifted off the support. Thus, the generalized coordinates which describe theelastic vibration of the girder, and the free length and strain of the falling wire rope at time t are also interdependent during this process and their relationship is (27)

sec.title: 3.4 Dynamic equations of system
sec.p:
The dynamic process of the lifting mechanism can be classified into two types.
Type-I: This process corresponds to the one in which a dynamic system is subjected to the constraints given by equations (26) and (27). This is likely to take place in the period when the payload supported is lifted upward.
Type-II: This process corresponds to the one in which a dynamic system is only subjected to the constraint given by equation (26). This takes place in the period when the payload is being suspended or it is already placed on its support.

sec.title: 3.4.1 Type-I
sec.p: Define a modified Lagrangian [23, 30] for the processas (28)

In this process, ZQ=constant and Z·Q=0. Through Hamilton’s principle ∫t1t2(δL+δW)dt=0 and ignoring small quantities of higher orders, it follows that (29) (30) (31) (32) with
Thus, a set of equations, equations (9), (10), (12) (or equation (13)), equations (26), (27), and (29)–(32), make up the system dynamic equations of the electrical overhead travelling crane controlled by the control system of changing the rotor resistance during type-I process during the lifting operation. Another set of equations, equations (9), (10), (14) (or equation (15), or equations (16)), (17)–(27) and equations (29)–(32), make up the system dynamic equations of the electrical overhead travelling crane controlled by the rotor-flux-oriented vector control system during type-I process during the lifting operation.

sec.title: 3.4.2 Type-II
sec.p: A modified Lagrangian [23, 30] was defined for the process as (33)
Through Hamilton's principle and ignoring small quantities of higher orders, the following equations can be derived: (34) (35) (36) (37)

A set of equations, equations (9), (10), (12) (or equation (13)), equations (26), and (34)–(37), make up the system dynamic equations of the electrical overhead travelling crane controlled by the control system of changing the rotor resistance during type-II process during the lifting operation. Another set of equations, equations (9), (10), and (14) (or equation (15) or (16)), equations (17) to (26) and (34) to (37), make up the system dynamic equations of the electrical overhead travelling crane controlled by the rotor-flux-oriented vector control system during type-II process during the lifting operation.
For ɛ=0 and mQ=0, i.e. when the crane carries no load and the mass of the load-handling device isignored, the dynamic equations (34) to (37) are reduced to
In this case, the dynamic response of the structure will not be related to the dynamic behaviour of the lifting mechanism and its drive system.

From these dynamic equations, it can be seen as follows.
The mass matrix, stiffness matrix, damping matrix, and force vector of system are time-varying while the lifting mechanism is in the transient state.
Unless the wire rope is slack, in lifting processes the steel structure, the motor drive, and the lifting mechanism influence one another because of the interaction among them. If the wire rope is slack, dynamic interaction exists only between the lifting mechanism and its drive system.
The variation of the supply voltage and the parameters of the main circuit of the drive motor, the braking torque, the constraint variation, and the varying length and the strain of the falling wire rope can all be sources of excitation during the lifting processes. The dynamic loads are a result of dynamic interaction among the electric motor, the girders, and the lifting mechanism.

sec.title: 3.5 Dynamic processes during lifting operation
sec.p: When a payload is lifted from its support, it is likely that both types of dynamic processes described above will be experienced and transition between them due to vibration will take place several times. If the load-handling device links unilaterally and rigidly with the payload and there is a gap between them, the first phase of type-II, type-I, and the second phase oftype-II occur in sequence. In the first phase of type-II, mQ is only the mass of the load-handling device. If the load-handling device is in contact with the payload and kwɛ+cwɛ·<mQg, the process will pass from type-I to the second phase of type-II. Otherwise, it will directly evolve into the second type-II process.
When a suspended payload is lifted or lowered from its stationary position, only the second phase of type-II processes takes place.

Only two type-II processes take place when a payload is lowered onto its support because the constraint of the payload is unilateral, and the lifting mechanism will continue to run for a short time after a payload has been lowered to its support.

When the load-handling device links with the payload by auxiliary wire ropes and the elasticity of them cannot be ignored, the payload and the load-handling device should be given an independent degree-of-freedom each.

It is very important to prevent hook slippage when a payload suspended is being carried. Two control schemes are carried out during the lifting operation. They are:
Release of the mechanical brake must lag behind energizing the motor during starting.
Application of the mechanical brake must lead to de-energizing of the motor during braking.

Thus, the rest of the component with the moment of inertia Jr and/or Jd will be included during starting and braking if the brake is assembled on the shaft of the rotor and/or the high-speed shaft of the gear reducer. In these cases, the dynamic equations can be reduced by deleting the rows in the equations involving θrand/or θd and substituting the value of θr and/or θd at rest and θ·r=0 and/or θ·d=0 to equations (9), (18), (21), (25), (30), (35), and/or equation (26). It is likely that the transition between the rest of component Ji(i=d,r) and the rotation of component Ji(i=d,r) will take place several times in the stage when the brake is in operation.

Furthermore, the dynamic equations should be reduced by deleting the rows in the equations involving is and substituting is and i·s with zero vector in the relevant equations (9), (10), (30), and (35), when the motor is in the power-off condition during braking.

sec.title: 4 NUMERICAL EXAMPLE
sec.p: As an example, a normal upward lifting process from the starting, the steady state at full speed, to the braking for a suspended payload at rest of a real electric overhead crane of 32T with the lifting height of 40 m controlled by the speed control system of changing the rotor resistance is investigated.

Figure 5 illustrates the rotor resistance of the control scheme during the hoisting operation [24]. The origin of the time variable is the moment when the motor is energized. Rr0 is the rotor resistance per phase of the motor at its preparation gear and Rri(i=1,2,3,and 4) the rotor resistance per phase after the ith segment of external rotor resistance is cut off from the motor's rotor circuit during starting process. When the motor operates at its first and second gears, its rotor resistance per phase are Rr1 and Rr2, respectively. When the motor operates at its third gear, its rotor resistance per phase is Rr3 first and then Rr4. The motor with rotor resistance Rri(i=0,1,2,and 3) is used for regulating speed and not allowed to run for a long time. Here, t1 and t4-t3 are set by the control system; t2 and t3-t2 refer to time difference tgsi(i=1,2) when the operating handle is shifted into (i + 1)-th gear and ith gear during starting, but their minimum values are set by the control system. Here, t5-t3 is determined by the action time of the contactor in the main circuit of the motor and the duration when the operating handle stays at the full speed gear together. Also, t6-t5 and t7-t6 are the time differences tgbi(i=2,1) when the operating handle is shifted out of ith and (i + 1)-th gears during braking, respectively. Fig. 5
Rotor resistance scheme during upward hoisting operation

For the lifting mechanism, typically a mechanical brake is attached to the high-speed shaft of the gear reducer, i.e., Mbs1 = 0 and Mbs2 ≠ 0. The above braking scheme is adopted in the crane under investigation. Although the friction mechanism is complex, plenty of tests by the brake manufacturers and the report in Severin and Dorsch [31] indicate that the mean friction coefficient in the drum/disc brake used in cranes is relatively invariable after right run-in process of the friction lining. Considering the variation process of the pressure between the brake drum/disc and the friction lining is approximately linear during the release and application processes of the mechanical brake, the braking capacity of the mechanical brake during the lifting process is presumed to be the time function, as shown in Fig. 6. The rationality of theassumption can also be validated by the test results of a braking process of the lifting mechanism by means of the mechanical brake (Fig. 7) [32]. Fig. 6
Braking capacity Mbs2 of mechanical brake Fig. 7
Pressure, friction force, and rotating speed of brake drum during braking of mechanical brake [32]

In Fig. 6, t8 is determined by the action time of the brake mainly [24], and the control system can be used to assist in getting an appropriate value of t8 if necessary. Also, t10 is determined by the moment when the operating handle is shifted out of its first gear position during braking and the action time of the brake. The time differences, t9-t8 and t11-t10, just rely on the action time of the brake.

The parameters used in this simulation are given in Table 1. In this table, l0 is the free length of the falling rope when the lifting mechanism start to move upward, toff is the time when the motor is turned off, and toff-t7 is determined by the control system. Also, ξw, ξs, and ξg are the damping ratios corresponding to cw, cs, and cg, respectively. The location of the girder sections under wheel O4 and wheel O4′ corresponding to the value of yo3 in this table is the so-called location of the most unfavourable sections of the girders. Table 1

Ls = 1.385 × 10 −2 H Rr2 = 1.05 Ω t10 − t7 = 0.157 s ωs = 314 rad/s

The MATLAB programs are coded to conduct the dynamic simulation. First, an upward normal lifting operation with a full payload suspended, which has the fastest variation rate of the rotor resistance during starting and braking, is investigated. This case is called the basic scenario hereinafter. Then, the effects of changing some parameters in the basic scenario are examined. The minimum value of tgbi(i=1,2) is assumed to be 0.2 s in this simulation.

sec.title: 4.1 Currents and power of motor
sec.p:
Figures 8(a) to (c) and 9(a) to (c) give the dynamic response of the three-phase stator and rotor currents of the motor in the basic scenario. It is noticed from the numerical results that: the three-phase stator and rotor currents may become steady in a few seconds; bigger peak currents are produced at every instant of cutting-off of the external rotor resistances; both the maximum stator and rotor currents arise after component Jd starts to rotate during starting; and the currents' amplitudes during braking are smaller than the amplitudes of their steady values. The amplitudes of the rotor and stator currents during the steady state, 129 and 131.9 A, agree quite well with the rated rotor and stator currents of the motor, 94 and 93.6 A, which are the root mean square values. Fig. 8
Time history of three-phase stator currents during the lifting operation in the basic scenario Fig. 9
Time history of three-phase rotor currents during the lifting operation in the basic scenario

After investigating the influence of tgsi(i=1,2) on the maximum transient currents during lifting, it is found that only duration tgs1 has some effect on them when changing tgsi(i=1,2), respectively (Fig. 10). At different locations of the payload, which are related to the length of the falling rope and the position of the trolley, results similar to those in Fig. 10 are obtained. Fig. 10
The influence of tgs1 on maximum stator and rotor currents during the lifting operation

Figure 11(a) and (b) displays the time histories of the electric power input from power supply to the motor and the mechanical power output from the motor to the lifting mechanism in the basic scenario. These indicate that a larger electric power loss takes place during starting and braking, especially before thethird lifting gear during starting and after the component Jd has been braked during braking. In fact, this is also a weakness of the control system. Fig. 11
The comparison of motor power in the basic scenario

Furthermore, it is found that the currents through the windings of the motor mainly depend on the payload, and as expected, the heavier the payload, the larger the maximum transient and steady values of the rotor and stator currents. It is worthwhile to note that the stator and rotor currents are also quitehigh during starting in the case of no-load (Fig. 12 (a) and (b)). Fig. 12
A-phase stator and rotor currents during the lifting operation with no-load

sec.title: 4.2 Dynamic load in rope
sec.p:
Figure 13 shows the time history of the rope load in the basic scenario. As expected, the rope load is equal to its steady value, the total weight of the payload and the load-handling device, prior to drum rotation. During starting, the rope load starts to increase from its steady value and then fluctuates. At first, the mean value of the dynamic rope load is more than its steady value; gradually, it oscillates around its steady value until it decays to the steady value due to damping if the lifting operation at the full speed gear is long enough. During braking, the rope load starts to decrease from the steady value and fluctuates again. First, the mean value of the dynamic rope load is less than its steady value, and then oscillates around its steady value step by step until the rope load again equals the steady load due to damping. The maximum rope loads during starting appear after component Jd rotates. The maximum rope loads during braking when unaffected by the starting process arise after the component Jd is stopped. Fig. 13
Time history of rope load in the basic scenario

During the lifting process, the frequency, the peak, and the amplitude of the rope load are closely related to the mass of the payload, the length of the rope, the position of the trolley, and the operator's operation.

The shorter the rope length is and the further from the middle of the girder the position of the trolley is located, the higher the frequency of the rope load is during starting and braking (Fig. 14(a) and (b)). In particular, as shown in Fig. 14(c) and (d), the frequency components of the rope load response are more complicated if the payload is lifted up and braked near to its upper limit at the middle of the girder. Fig. 14
Time history of rope load at different locations of payload

The maximum and minimum values of the rope load during the lifting process when braking process is not affected by the starting process depend on the location of the payload when the motor starts accelerating or decelerating, and this relationship is non-linear (Figs 15 and 16). It is observed that the global maximum of the rope load occurs during starting and braking in which the payload is near the upper limit of lifting range, i.e., l is about 9 m, and the trolley is located at its left limit, i.e., yo3 is 0.245 m if the payload being lifted happens to be the rated payload. Because of symmetry, there should be a similar result when the trolley is located at its right limit. Fig. 15
Maximum and minimum rope loads during starting at different locations of payload Fig. 16
Maximum and minimum rope loads during braking at different locations of payload

The magnitude of the rope load is also very sensitive totgsi(i=1,2) and tgbi(i=1,2) if duration tgs1 and tgs2 are longer than their minimum durations set by the control system. Upward starting processes of a suspended full-load payload with different tgs1 values, in which yo3 is 0.245 m and the lifting mechanism starts to run when l is 9 m, are used to illustrate the effect (Fig. 17). In Fig. 17, four circles mark the rope loads at the instants when the motor runs into its second starting gear when duration tgs1 is equal to 0.2, 0.37, 0.52, and 0.65 s, respectively. It is found that very small duration difference can result in a great difference of the response of rope load. Both the maximum value and amplitude of the rope force fluctuate with increasing duration tgs1. Fig. 17
Rope load–time histories during starting in different tgs1 values

The transient state of the rope load last much longer than those of the stator and rotor currents. Therefore, the rope load during braking must also be affected significantly by the dynamic load induced by starting if the noticeable oscillation that was excited in the starting process has not disappeared when braking happens (Fig. 18). Fig. 18
Rope load–time histories during braking in different tg3 values

From the results shown in Figs 17 and 18, it can be seen that the slower operation of operators, i.e. the smaller average lifting acceleration or deceleration, is not always able to result in a smaller maximum value and amplitude of the rope load. Moreover, the effect of the payload mass is obvious. The smaller the mass of the payload, the higher the frequency and the smaller the amplitude of the rope load.

sec.title: 4.3 Dynamic response of high-speed shaft in lifting mechanism
sec.p:
Figure 19 shows the time histories of the electromagnetic torque of the motor, the rotating speed of the component Jd, the torque applied to the high-speed shaft, and the braking capacity of the mechanical brake in the basic scenario. Fig. 19
Dynamic response of the high-speed shaft in the basic scenario

Figure 20 shows the relationships of the rotor speed–electromagnetic torque when the motor is in the basic scenario and steady states. All data shown inthese figures have been converted back with respect to the high-speed shaft. It is found that the transient state of the motor does not end until the motor is shifted into its third gear during starting. During braking, the motor runs at a steady state basically. Therefore, the dynamic simulation for an electric crane should consider the transient state of its drive motor. Fig. 20
The comparison of rotor speed-electromagnetic torque of the motor in the basic scenario and steady states

It is further observed that the high-speed shaft will undergo vibration with different mean values and amplitudes because the motor operates at different gears and the mechanical brake is released and applied successively. The peak torque applied to the high-speed shaft is a few times as big as the rated torque of the motor, 582 Nm. The high-speed shaft is subjected to the torque with higher amplitude and lower frequency and even the reversed torque, when component Jd cannot rotate due to application of the mechanical brake during starting and braking. Furthermore, although there is greater vibration in the system, the speeds of the rotor and component Jd are fairly smooth because of the filtering characteristic of the physical system.

From Fig. 19, it is clearly seen that component Jd has rotated before the mechanical brake is released completely. This indicates that there has been enough capacity to lift the rated payload after the motor is shifted into its first gear. Therefore, the braking scheme, by which the release of the mechanical brake lags after the motor moves into the operation at the second gear and at the third gear, should be avoided. Otherwise, the high-speed shaft will experience higher peak load (Fig. 21). Two circles indicate the torques experienced by the high-speed shaft at the instant when the motor is entering its second gear during starting in the event that t8 values are 0.132 and 0.321 s, respectively. Fig. 21
Influence over peak torque due to variation of t8 (see Fig. 19 for the line codes)

The case in which t8 is more than mint2 is avoidable by sensibly adjusting the time parameters given by the control system. For example, one solution is to slightly increase the set value of t2 − t1 in the programmable logic controller program in order to make t8 less than mint2, because in this case, the peak load when tgs1 is more than mint2 will never be more than the peak load when mint2 is not less than tgs1 (Fig. 22). This suggests that the amplitude of the torque applied to the high-speed shaft may be bounded when the release of the mechanical brakeslightly precedes the moment when the motor is shifted into its second gear during starting. Fig. 22
Measure of restraining peak torque characteristics experienced by the high-speed shaft

From equations (30) and (35), it can be seen that the rotation and the torque of the high-speed shaft are related to the rope load, the operator’s operation, the motor control, and the braking capacity of the mechanical brake. After investigating the dynamic responses of the high-speed shaft at various locations of the payload when the lifting mechanism starts, a very small difference between these loads of the high-speed shaft during the rotation of component Jd can be seen because of the lower lifting speed in the example; and the most obvious difference between them occurs after the motor enters its third gear operation and lasts for a period of time. Therefore, it is likely that the effect of the rope load on the dynamic response of high-speed shaft with the peak torque which is a few times of the rated torque of the motor is mainly determined by the weight of thepayload. There is still a significant torque in the high-speed shaft during starting and braking with no-load due to the application of the mechanical brake (Fig. 23). Fig. 23
Time history of the torque of the high-speed shaft with no-load

Moreover, a larger braking capacity of the mechanical brake also enhances the torque experienced by the high-speed shaft and decreases the braking time of the mechanism. Incidentally, a larger braking capacity of the mechanical brake also leads to a greater maximum value of the response in the rope load, and the bending moment and dynamic elastic deformation of the girder during braking definitely. All the durations except tgs2 significantly affect the torque experienced by the high-speed shaft as long as duration tg3 is short enough. From the simulation, the variation of the rope length and the displacement of the payload are also found. These will not be presented in detail due to limitation of space.

sec.title: 4.4 Bending moment of girders
sec.p:
The fluctuation of bending moment of the girder is similar to that of the rope load. The influencing factors are similar to those of the rope load as well, i.e. their frequencies and amplitudes depend on the location and the mass of the payload; their amplitudes are closely related to the operator’s operation as well. However, some high-frequency components in the bending moment which are present in the rope load are not found when the payload is lifted up to near its upper limit in the middle of the girder. Figure 24(a) and (b) allows a comparison between the bending moment in the most unfavourable section of the girder and rope load during starting and braking as mentioned above. Fig. 24
Bending moments of girder and rope loads during starting and braking

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this article, an idea for comprehensive dynamic modelling of electric cranes is put forward. In this idea, the dynamics of the control system, the steel structure, and mechanisms are considered simultaneously so that a more appropriate design solution and control scheme corresponding to different control systems can be established to improve the performance of electric cranes. In addition, the load information of the components in the mechanism and structure can be estimated in more detail in the design stage.

A series of numerical simulations of realistic hoisting operations of a real electric overhand crane, which is controlled by the speed control system of changing the rotor resistance, have been performed. No such an attempt has been reported in the open literature to the authors’ best knowledge. From the numerical results of the simulated crane operations, it can be concluded that:
Payload is the most influential factor on the dynamic responses of the mechanism, the structure, and the motor, which are also very sensitive to the operator's operation. However, a decrease inthe operator’s operating speed does not lead to a monotonic decrease in the peak of the dynamic responses.
The location of payload mainly affects the load of the rope and the girders, whereas the braking capacity of the mechanical brake and the moment when the mechanical brake is released during starting have stronger effects on the load of the lifting mechanism.
A better design philosophy of electrical cranes should consider the stochastic nature of the loads involved due to the uncertainty in the operation of these cranes.
These simulation results of the lifting mechanism support the classification of the service condition of the mechanism in terms of the average number of acceleration in an operation cycle, rather than the run time hours of the mechanism, in the newprovisions of the Europe crane standard EN 13001 [33].

ack.p: Congmin Niu and Hongwu Zhang are grateful for the support of Natural Science Foundation of China (grant no. 1072106). Congmin Niu is very grateful for the technical support of Freescale Semiconductor, Inc., in understanding the vector control system and also to Weicheng Shen of Jiaozhuo Brake Incorporated Company in China who provided the test results of the mechanical brake. Professor D. Severin of Technical University of Berlin kindly provided a dissertation of one of his assistants.
